author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Urban Outfitters asked some employees to work for free
text:
Jen Grantham via iStock The parent company of Urban Outfitters asked some employees to work for free during October weekends. Urban Outfitters is not in the giving mood this holiday season.
Parent company URBN Inc. is asking salaried employees to volunteer to work weekends in a Pennsylvania fulfillment center for free, according to an email obtained by Gawker.
They’re selling it as a “team-building activity”.
“As a volunteer, you will work side by side with your GFC colleagues to help pick, pack and ship orders for our wholesale and direct customers,” the email said.
The email also describes the volunteer work as “a great way to experience our fulfillment operations first hand.” at the Gap, Pa. center.
The rewards for the the free six-hour labor are lunch and transportation.
Urbanoutfitters.com The hipster-friendly store often comes under fire for selling offensive articles of clothing, such as thiswomen's T-shirt depicting the word "Depression." The company was looking to fill two shifts daily on weekends this month, with a note that volunteers could sign up for multiple days.
URBN Inc. — which also owns Antropologie, Free People, Terrain and wedding line BHLDN — said they had “unsurprisinly received a tremendous response,” according to a statement given to Gawker.
“Many hourly employees also offered to pitch in – an offer which we appreciated, but declined in order to ensure full compliance with all applicable labor laws and regulations,” the company told Gawker.
The news overshadowed other news that was announced Wednesday about the store.
Urban Outfitters in New York will end on-call scheduling, a practice that has come under fire as it requires worker to report for shifts on short notice.
MDOSTIS@NYDAILYNEWS.COM
